name: 3 Builds to choose but im incompetent
author: n8tronic

posts.author: n8tronic
posts.content:
(not sure if I can even post this)
Hi I have been searching for several days for updated builds and this is the site that i landed on from the old ECB thats more than 10 years old and i assume most of those builds no longer work in the new updates.
I found some builds from this site that are new.
I played this game in highschool and it was my first intro into DnD and there is WAY too much to know so i just winged that game but really enjoyed it even though i had no idea what i was doing. So here i am again with the new EE version and want to actually know what im doing this time around.
 If you could please help me understand the differences and choose one of these 3 builds and just help a general noob learn to play.
Here are the builds i found that focus on Druid and Dragon shape or shape shifting
1.the-wild-heart-focused-rakhasa-dragon-s ... 55079.html
2.the-world-ender-druid-32-fighter-2-monk-6-t2355416.html
3.viewtopic.php?p=16163#p16163

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
I would suggest "The World Ender) by GDL.

I am currently playing it, and it is a beast! (oh, a pun!).

Where will you be playing this?

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Greetings and hello n8tronic!

And welcome back to Neverwinter! That is quite a nice list of dragon builds you have chosen. 

I would add Maximillan Kane's Champion of the Wilderness, my Skilled and Sneaky Arch-Druid and Kail Pendragon's Nature's Wyrm to your list of v1.69 compatible ECB Dragon Shape builds. 

That way, you now have a full smorgasboard and we can make it even harder for you to decide which one!

Druid dragon builds (or druid shifter dragons) have a common element:

1. Try to get Dragon Shape around level 30-33
2. This means focusing on getting wisdom to 30 ASAP, through Starting Wis 18, +Wis every level up, Taking Great Wisdoms as general epic and bonus feats (from Druid, Champion of Torm or Shifter)
3. Take at least one level of Monk to make the dragon and other forms have Monk UBAB (meaning 5-7 attacks per round) and Monk Wisdom AC (meaning that high wisdom score is added to AC)

Beyond that one adds certain flavors.

Wildheart adds shifter shapes including Outsider Shape, Dragon Shape is delayed to level 35
World Ender is undispellable combat dragon with a lot of Monk Speed, a bit more Monk AC, a lot more tumble dumps throughout the build, caster level 32 is quite nice. 
Order of Jorumungandr v1.69+ is a combat dragon with dual cleric and druid spell books and dragon shape, but all buffs are dispellable.
Champion of the Wilderness is an undispellable combat dragon, probably has the highest unbuffed AB and highest attacks / round of the lot, Dragon Shape at level 31
Skilled and Sneaky Arch-Druid is a very high caster Druid (36 CL) with Rogue skills/UMD who gets Dragon Shape at level 30
Nature's Wyrm is a caster Druid (30 CL) who gets Dragon Shape at level 28, the fastest possible Dragon Shape that I have seen.

You will want to play a dragon build in an environment which allows leveling past level 36 to enjoy at least some dragon time.
Hence WebShaman's question where you plan to play this is a relevant one.

The Bioware Campaigns are not a good choice to take a dragon shape build to.
Shadows of Undrentide / Original Campaign will get you to about level 17-18. 
Hordes of the Underdark gets you to about level 28.
Therefore you will essentially not get to dragon shape. 

So it would be a custom module or persistent world you would want to take your build to. 

For the single player modules which have content up to close to level 40 I wrote this a few days ago:
Orion2019 wrote:
I can't remember the full list of single player modules but Aielund saga I-VI gets to level 36-38 which is pretty good, this is free at the NWN Vault

Others I hear about that are good are Mines of Twin Summit (to lvl 40), Sands of Fate (level 40)
Lord of Terror gets to 30 so grab that Bard1 /RDD 10 from level 21-29 
Bioware's Shadows of Undrentide and Hordes of the Underdark gets to 28 
Aribeth's Redemption looks like it gets to about 28 as well
Not sure about Swordflight I presume that goes quite high, but I hear it is quite difficult if you like that:) [Addition: Mick Dagger tells us mid to late 20s]
For persistent worlds you could choose Blackstone Keep or World of Greyhawk as they are environments which go to level 40. 
Dragon Shape builds tend to be most powerful in low to mid magic environments. 
High magic environments are less favorable to Dragon Shape.

There may be others that I have missed.

Hope that helps

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content: Great post, Orion!

Wow nice response! I never really thought about which campaigns I was just gonna take this guy through them all in succession!
Would you recommend that I skip the campaigns and download Aielund saga since its part of the steam workshop?
Also if you had to choose which build has the strongest power but doesnt require some complex gameplay? Is there a guide which tells me which spells of which level are best and perhaps some combos, that would be very helpful

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
If you wanted something without complex gameplay, I would choose Maximillan Kane's Champion of the Wilderness or Grizzled_Dwarflord's World Ender.
Maximillan Kane's build gets knockdown on his build at level 12 (Grizzled's gets knockdown/improved knockdown with Monk 6 late)
Grizzled however gets Monk early meaning your early polymorphs will be stronger (Max gets Monk 1 at level 22, half your leveling is already done by then).

You could adjust each build accordingly (ie take Knockdown instead of a different feat for Grizzled's build, or take Monk earlier in Max's build), however if you take Monk 1 before level 20 in Max's build you will lose one attack per round which may or may not matter really (6 APR vs 7 APR) depending on your perspective. 

In terms of guides... 


Maximillan Kane's Nature's Strongest Defenders - A Guide to Druids
Thaxll'ssyllia's All you need to know about Druids

Are good places to start.

There is also a NWN Wiki: Druid Strategies page which may have some useful information
Valerfor wrote a spell list in his Green Knight of Ehlonna build, I would study this he taught me a lot about building and playing druids

If you want a simplified version, use buffing spells before you polymorph (ie Bull's, Stoneskin, Owl's Insight)
Your summons and animal companion are good to deal damage with at the beginning but have terrible AC so you may have to 'tank damage' for them but that is difficult early levels.
Use Stonehold/Grease/Storm of Vengeance to disable mobs, this is very effective
Call lightning / Icestorm is great on wands but wands suffer late game due to low spell penetration

I tried my best to find all the character class guides out there in this post (ie all classes, including Druids and more), which may also be of interest to you. I'm adding to it intermittently as more guides are found or published.

Hope that helps!

Oh in terms of modules - if you want to play a dragon build, you will want to download a module which goes to close to level 40, or play a persistent world which goes to level 40, any of the choices listed should be ok, Aielund would be my choice for single player, returning to NWN, it is a great series of modules and the Dragon/Shifter build was playtested there. In terms of PWs World of Greyhawk would be my choice, Maximillan Kane, Grizzled_Dwarflord and Kail Pendragon (and definitely myself) would have playtested the dragon builds there, it is renowned for being a challenging environment, so some may or may not like that.

posts.author: n8tronic
posts.content:
Yes sir very helpful thankyou, I have decided on the World Ender (this is my third restart deciding on class)
Is there an active discord i can join?
Also this build doesnt have a level guide for skill points...

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hello and welcome aboard, n8tronic!

Others will have to help you when it comes to Persistent Worlds (though we do have a forum for them here in the Guild), but when it comes to modules, I would recommend Aielund above all - not that there's anything wrong with the others Orion cites. If you fancy Mines of Twin Summits (very high magic by the end), you probably want to play the OC first, as it's meant to take a character from about level 16/17 to 40. Equally, Sands of Fate is a good follow-on from SoU/HotU, as it takes you from around level 27 to 40. Pop down to our Modules forum for more details.

As to the skill points for the World Ender, I'm afraid only GDL can truly break his schedule down, but if it helps...

Only take Animal Empathy and Spellcraft on Druid levels. Only take Hide, Listen, Move Silently and Tumble (and take Tumble in batches of 5) on Monk levels. Only take Concentration and Discipline on Fighter or Monk levels (I'm afraid I can't remember atm whether Conc is a Druid skill or not, sorry). You can take Heal on whichever class you like, but Spot will have to be cross-classed as it isn't a skill any of the classes have. Essentially, "cross-classed" means you can only take a point in it every other level, so you can only get to half the max skill.

Hope that makes sense and is at least of a little use.

Cheers

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content: Druid has Concentration as a skill.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Cheers, Web. As you might have noticed, I don't exactly "do" casters, so am a little shaky on what they have/don't have.

So, n8tronic, you can take Concentration on all three classes, like Heal.

Hello and thankyou. Is it possible to mess up those points? As long as i have his end numbers?
From steam workshop i downloaded the Aeilund campaign and it works. It seems like steam workshop doesnt work for some of the content because it doesn’t distribute the files properly or something.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Oh, it's easily possible to mess up the points - done it myself plenty of times. One thing I've learned, though, if you save them up, you can always use them at your next level-up, or the one after, or whenever (skill points save in Neverwinter, which is a real blessing). For example, with the World Ender you've got 6 levels of Monk, and each level in that class (with 14 INT and being human) gets 7 skill points to distribute. Now, on those Monk levels you need to take, as a minimum, all your Hide, Listen, Move Silently and Tumble ranks. That means you're going to have to save some skill points from when you take another class so you can use them when you next take a level in Monk. GDL takes Monk at levels 7, 12, 17, and 22, which is no accident, because they are perfect for dropping in 10, then 5, then 5, and another 5 ranks in Tumble. He takes the final 2 levels at 30 and 40 because he has other priorities at that stage - or he'd have taken them at either 27 (or 32) and 37, so you'll need to take another 5 points at 30 and the remaining 10 at 40. The knack is simply to remember to take what you need when you can, and save any spare points for when you need them.

Afraid I can't help as far as Steam goes. I'm still playing v1.69 from disc, with all my downloads from the Vault. I know, I know...Others will be able to offer guidance, though, I'm sure. (Oh, and don't turn into a dragon when you're in a dungeon, unless it's got really big doors and a high ceiling. Just a tip.)

Cheers

Ok so i noticed he has a final number for the skill points. Is it not possible just to stick to those skills and end up with that number? So if I just Max the 3 druid skills at each level up and leave whats leftover and then when monk comes dump all my tumble in there and if he has a few ranks in hide and move silently put a few points into there. Then on druid levels keep maxing his 3 skills then when monk comes again dump all the tumble again etc. This should work no? Just make sure i never go over his posted number?

As a side note if i just fumble around and explore the areas fully will i be able to get most of the gameplay and secrets? I know from playing some planescape that if you dont choose certain dialogue at a certain time you can miss so really good items and stuff. Is that the case for nwn

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
That's exactly the point, n8tronic. But you may find you need to prioritize. For this build, I would suggest you always have sufficient skill points in your arsenal to max Concentration, Spellcraft and Tumble whenever you can (in other words, making you as good as you can be at casting and resisting spells, and boosting your AC every five levels or so). My own second tier would be Animal Empathy, Discipline, and Listen, closely followed by Hide and Move Silently. Leaving Heal and Spot as pretty much luxury items.

I will put a huge disclaimer on this. First, I don't play casters, so may be wildly off-beam. Second, this is how I would play it, others - yourself included - will probably be different.

Cheers

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
This is probably the best you will get
Valerfor wrote:

Spells used for buffing (In order of levels): Resistance, Endure elements, ultravision, barkskin, resist elements, bull's strength/ empowered bull's strength, protection from elements, freedom of movement, stoneskin, death ward, spell resistance, extended monstrous regeneration, energy buffer, greater stoneskin, extended regenerate, extended aura of vitality, true seeing, premonition.

Spells used for battlefield control: Entangle, grease, spike growth, vine mine, stonehold/ empowered stonehold, creeping doom, sunburst/ sunbeam, storm of vengeance.

Spells used for offense: Call lightning/ empowered call lightning, flame strike/ empowered flame strike, empowered ice storm, empowered crumble, drown, sunburst/ sunbeam, empowered firestorm.

Spells used for generic support: Elemental swarm, summon creature VIII (that is an elder elemental due to Druid advanced summons).

posts.author: n8tronic
posts.content:
webshaman1 wrote:
Apr 02, 2020
I would suggest "The World Ender) by GDL.

I am currently playing it, and it is a beast! (oh, a pun!).

Where will you be playing this?
Can you tell me how to use Expertise properly? And flurry of blows. Since you are playing the same build can you tell me how you normally approach a fight? That would be great thankyou

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Expertise (and FoB) can both be set to "stick" - meaning that you don't have to activate them for every fight.

Expertise only works for melee and, depending on the environment, while spellcasting (a module switch can be set to prevent this).

Basically, put both in your Quickbar.  You will want them on the first one (that one that you always see down at the bottom of the screen).

Then you need to just activate (either with a click or by hitting the appropriate F key corresponding to the Quickbar slot) it.

Expertise (and it's bigger brother Improved Expertise) lets you sacrifice AB for AC - meaning that for Expertise you get a -5/+5, and Impr. Expertise -10/+10.  This can really make a difference - especially if you have AB to burn (meaning you are easily hitting the enemy, but it is also easily hitting you) OR you can't hit the enemy at all (meaning you need a natural 20).  In the later case, it really doesn't matter if you have a minus to hit, because only a natural 20 hits.

FoB is a great combat feat that when activated, gives you an extra attack, with a -2 on all attacks.  It only works, however, with unarmed attacks and with monk kamas.

Since the World Eater...hehe.  Ok, I took liberties with the name.  World Ender.

Since the World Ender can shift to Dragon Form, and in that form has natural weaponry (meaning unarmed combat), it can benefit greatly from FoB.

Normally, without the "sticky" option being activated, FoB will have to be activated as you go into combat (or are in combat).  It takes one round to activate (it is not instantaneous).  When stickied, it will stay active until one no longer is fighting unarmed (or with kamas).

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
So how to approach a fight.

This really depends on if I know what is coming or not.

But let us say that I know.

Before the fight - buff up with all your buffs.  Summon aid.  Buff it. Lay down your defensive spells/AoEs, as you will.

Make sure you have the right items in the right spots. Cast your offensive AoEs. Shift.  Masticate.  Either stay shifted and continue to masticate, or shift back. 

If you do not know what is coming, then be more cautious.  Have your long term buffs up.  Animal Companion out and long term buffed.  Explore, when the enemy is sighted, I normally look to see what kind of enemy it is.  If I think I can take it easily, I just melee (or range) it in normal form.  If it looks threatening, then kill it with fire, tooth, and claw (meaning the very above strategy).

The reason for this is to conserve your resources as much as possible.  This is a good routine to get into, imo.  You never know when you will need to use those spells/shifts and being in a situation without them because you lazily squandered them could prove detrimental.

Nice thanks. How do i set them to “stick” Normally you go into every fight with expertise stuck on? Or FoB?
Also before dragon shape i assume you use the elemental shapes? Which ones are good to use? I noticed that the air and water ones have a spell they can use but i dont know what they do other than the water one hurts itself too
Also

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
I wouldn't go into every fight with expertise stuck on - expertise is one of those types of feats that one needs to consider if it is worth and/or necessary to have active.

FoB I often have active, but only when I am not fighting with weapons (other than a kama).

You can set them to sticky in the NWN EE control panel.

The Elemental Shapes have fantastic properties!

Since they also work on the "merge" basis, it is a good idea to know what merges.

This is a pretty good guide - zelle-s-shifter-guide-version-v-revisited-t2209096.html

As to which one to use, well, it really depends!  Each one has some properties (besides the ones they all have) that make them unique.

Aside from what they are immune to, that is.

Here are your shapes and what they do - both the normal and epic https://nwn.fandom.com/wiki/Elemental_shape

I personally do not use the Drown attack of the Water Elemental, but the Whirlwind attack of the Air Elemental could be of use, I suppose -
An air elemental can create a small whirlwind, knocking all enemies to the ground and causing any who fall 1d3 points of slashing damage for every two levels of the elemental.
.

I normally just beat my enemies to death.

Very useful info thanks. So the “stick” option is not in game but in the control panel, where can i find that? I tried to google it with no luck. Im still unclear as to what it actually does. So I would just select the skill and instead of the game turning it off when i move, it would just be constantly on at all times until i click to turn it off? I know that expertise shuts off if i move i think so it would just activate again on its own?

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
CTRL + SHIFT + F12

You will then see up in the upper lefthand corner of your NWN screen (you can do this anywhere in NWN) a list of things.  You want Config for this one.

Under Config -> StickyCombatModes.

Put a check in it.

Then go up, and hit confirm.

CTRL + SHIFT + F12 to get back out.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
What Sticky does is "stick" those combat type modes to On or Off when clicked on, unless something happens that would invalidate them (like equipping a shield and weapon other than a Kama for FoB).

When the icon in your Quickbar is clicked on (or the appropriate F key) the mode "sticks" - this means that you don't always have to be hammering away at the FoB button all the time as you enter combat, etc.

Same goes for Power Attack, Expertise, etc.  Just keep in mind that these will now stay on, and you may wonder why you are missing so much in combat...

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
n8tronic wrote:

Also before dragon shape i assume you use the elemental shapes? Which ones are good to use? I noticed that the air and water ones have a spell they can use but i dont know what they do other than the water one hurts itself too
Web's advice is pretty good in general
In terms of shapes I use three in combat most of the time when I play druid but happy to learn what others do:

1. Bear / Dire Bear form -> highest AB/strength of the animal shapes, its great for damage, can carry mountains of loot, with Monk AC it covers its weakness (low AC) and Monk UBAB is pretty nice with it

2. Water elemental / Elder water elemental form -> I like this form over the others as it has a nice balance between stats ie AB / AC etc compared with the other elementals. It is mind immune, petrify immune, paralysis immune, critical hit immune, sneak immune, immune to fire damage, disease. AB / Damage is more than the Bear form, but infinite elemental shapes come later than infinite wildshapes.

3. Ancient Green Dragon or Ancient Blue Dragon shape -> acid or electrical immunity is pretty good with no elemental vulnerabilities. I like the acid immunity better so I can ignore Mestil's Acid Sheath in battle. Ancient Red Dragon is situational if there is a big fire damage user

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
I use whatever weapon the environment gives me that is advantageous.  Scimitar is probably the one I would look for first. Note that this build has Zen Archery, so doing ranged is going to be a priority over melee in normal form.  But if I came across a good Kama, sure, I would use it.

Why not?

I personally do not bother much with the Wildshape forms - invest skill points in Animal Empathy and, depending on your environment, you will have an army to fight for you, while you stand back and range away, mixing in spells as needed.  It just is more effective to fight this way than to use wildshape forms imo.  The Elemental forms are worth using, imo.

Where I currently am, I use soley the Earth Elemental form.  It packs a punch, and that is what I need for the opponents I am currently fighting.  I like to deal damage - but it does "suffer" from lower AC.  Not a real problem when buffed.  Like I mentioned before, it is really dependent on the environment and the enemies one faces. 

Orion is right when he mentions the Water Elemental form as being "the most rounded" imo.

Dragon form, well, it's the "now I will show you TRUE power!" mighty munchkin power ranger!  It's really the reason for the build, and for most Dragon builds...thus the name. I normally stick to the Green Dragon due to Mestil's - but again, dependent on the environment.

posts.author: n8tronic
posts.content: Ok I guess anytime i would want to be in melee im hopefully gonna be able to shape change and not worry that my weapon cant use FoB

posts.author: grizzled_dwarflord
posts.content: I use the Expertise line early on when I want to tank and let my associates deal damage. Once your AC starts to get up there it doesn't have as much value.  It's practically a necessity, though, if using Wyrmling shape.  It has other uses in other shapes.  Like in Stone Golem shape I'll turn it on and spam Hurl Rocks.  It doesn't affect your splash damage chance to hit from the hurled boulders.  The same is true for most forms that have a special ability (manticore spikes, Iron Golem Poison Fumes, Dragon Breath, etc.)

After playing for quite some time now I have a few more questions that I cant seem to find answers for.
I have Chromatic breastplate which gives elements resistance/ 10 now if i use a protection from elements spell does it stack with my armor?
Also does the endure elements and protection from elements spell line stack? Or does the strongest one overwrite the rest?
Thankyou

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
I think those are great questions
The elemental resistance only works once when I play.
Ie your Chromatic Breastplate and a Endure Elements spell -> only one source of elemental resistance will work at a time
So only 10 damage resistance to fire damage for example.

As to which one is used up first I am unsure.
I suspect the endure or protect from eles spell from playing but I could be wrong.

As for stacking endure elements and protection from elements I know that only one ele resist will work at a time (ie prot from ele 30 damage reduction).
but I am unsure if the endure elements can be 'held in reserve' that is once the prot from elements is used up, the endure elements can be then used.

I know that stoneskin (+5/10-) / premonition (+5/30-) can be active at the same time but only one source of damage reduction is used first. 
Premonition is used up first, once used up, then stoneskin can be used to protect the mage until that is used up.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
This spell stacks with — and is applied after — feat-based sources of damage resistance.
So, no, it will not stack with DR of the same kind, nor that on Armor, Rings, etc.

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
DRes from spells or items won't stack with any other DRes from spells or items, they only stack with DRes from feats.

PfE gives 30/- elemental DRes and so it takes priority over the 10/- elemental DRes on your armor. Bear in mind that it will take priority even if you have less than 10 points of DRes left on your PfE spell, so it is possible to take more damage with PfE than without it. This works similarly for the entire elemental resistance spell line, Energy Buffer (40/- DRes) will take priority over PfE even if it has less than 30 points of DRes left. It's not possible to stack the same elemental resistance spell, but you can cast all four elemental resistance spells and they will apply one after the other.

If the items have a higher DRes than the spell (eg 35/- elemental DRes or better for PfE) then the item DRes will apply and the spell won't trigger.

If the items have the same DRes as the spell (eg 30/- elemental DRes for PfE) then the first effect is applied first. For example, if the item is equipped before you cast PfE then the item DRes is used and PfE won't trigger. However if PfE is used before you equip the item (or if you unequip and then reequip the item after casting PfE), then PfE will be used before the item DRes.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content: Great response Yunim, many thanks

Yunim wrote:
Apr 08, 2020

PfE gives 30/- elemental DRes and so it takes priority over the 10/- elemental DRes on your armor. Bear in mind that it will take priority even if you have less than 10 points of DRes left on your PfE spell, so it is possible to take more damage with PfE than without it. This works similarly for the entire elemental resistance spell line, Energy Buffer (40/- DRes) will take priority over PfE even if it has less than 30 points of DRes left. It's not possible to stack the same elemental resistance spell, but you can cast all four elemental resistance spells and they will apply one after the other.

If the items have a higher DRes than the spell (eg 35/- elemental DRes or better for PfE) then the item DRes will apply and the spell won't trigger.

If the items have the same DRes as the spell (eg 30/- elemental DRes for PfE) then the first effect is applied first. For example, if the item is equipped before you cast PfE then the item DRes is used and PfE won't trigger. However if PfE is used before you equip the item (or if you unequip and then reequip the item after casting PfE), then PfE will be used before the item DRes.
Ok great response! So I can not just cast them all on myself because the strongest one will just overwrite the weaker ones correct? Or will the weaker spells “stay in reserve” and once the stronger one is used up the weaker one will take its place?
As to my armor does the resistance on my armor get used up as well or is it just permanent that the first 10 damage from any element never gets through my armor?

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Resistance on the armor is permanent.

Unless a Rust Monster gets too cuddly, of course.

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
The spells will stay in reserve. You can have all four elemental resistance spells active on your character at once, but when you take damage only one will work at a time. In order of priority it goes Energy Buffer (40/- DR), then Protection From Elements (30/- DR), then Resist Elements (20/- DR), then Endure Elements (10/- DR).

For example, let's say you wear your armor (10/- DR) and then cast both RE (20/- DR) and PfE (30/- DR). PfE has the highest DR (30/-) and so takes priority, followed by RE (20/-) and then the armor (10/-). Once PfE wears off then RE will activate, and it is only after both PfE and RE have worn off that the DR from your armor will be used. As webshaman1 says, the DR on your armor is permanent and will not wear off.

One thing to note is that this priority holds even if it is technically worse for your character. Let's say you're wearing your 10/- elemental DR armor but are down to 5 points of Fire DR left on your RE and you get hit with 10 Fire damage. Since RE takes priority your DR will absorb 5 points of Fire damage and then wear off, which results in you taking 5 Fire damage. If you didn't have RE then your armor would have blocked the 10 Fire damage and you would be unharmed.

Since RE takes priority your DR will absorb 5 points of Fire damage and then wear off, which results in you taking 5 Fire damage. If you didn't have RE then your armor would have blocked the 10 Fire damage and you would be unharmed.

Creatures with breath weapons, elementals, weapons with elemental properties, traps, etc.

I have a question about gearing. Since I have a monk level would it be best to wear monk robes? (In chapter 2 there is monk armor with haste) what kind of gear should i be on the lookout for other than +wisdom

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
n8tronic wrote:
In chapter 2 there is monk armor with haste
Monk robes would allow you to make the most of your high wisdom score by boosting AC in druid form
They would be ideal if you have a good set.
Also allow you to have other monk abilities such as Monk UBAB and Monk Speed, if you have these

I would hang onto those robes if I were you, you should be hasted when polymorphed
Haste also adds +4 dodge AC which might help

In terms of items I would suggest good items which can be put on the helmet, armor or shield slot
This is because magical properties on those items will transfer to your bear form, elemental form or dragon shape.
Certain properties do not stack. For example only the highest AC bonus on the three items noted above will count. 
So if you have a +2 robes and +1 shield, the AC will be transferred as +2 deflection.
I haven't played the OC for a while in terms of specifics
There may be some useful information in NWN Wiki: Wildshape and NWN Wiki: Dragon shape if you are interested

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
n8tronic wrote:
Apr 12, 2020
I see, so even tho my armor shield and helm are merged is my shifted forms using UBAB and monk speed?
While you're right about the UBAB, I'm afraid armour and shield do nullify monk speed (your hat's alright). I haven't played a shifter or druid, so can't pass comment on whether merging impacts on that. I'm sure others will know.

So Web's aforementioned cheese is for the UBAB, not the speed. The Robes of the Dark Moon you mention earlier do still grant Haste, though, and are (imho) the best you'll get for a monk in the OC, and they free up your boots slot for those great monk slippers of the Sun Soul (up to +5 in the OC, iirc) for another +5 to AC.

Cheers

EDIT: Oh, and unless things are different from normal in shifted forms, you'd also lose your whopping 13 Monk AC wisdom bonus if you carry a shield or wear armour (again, hats are fine).

What is this “bummer” you speak of?

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Well, say you are in the middle of combat, and desperately (for whatever reason) need to shift back to your normal form.

BAM!

Because you are wearing armor, shield, etc, your defenses are suddenly crap due to Wis based AC loss, etc.  Because one often cannot change armor, etc in the middle of combat.

And of course, the # 1 killer bummer of them all - forgetting to swap "pieces".  That one always gets me.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I suspect that's about putting your armour and shield on just before shifting, then taking them both off again once you unshift, or you will lose the monk AC and speed. And you've got to remember to do that every time. It's like buffing before doing anything, but then having to de-buff each time you leave combat, rather than letting them wear off. Which would become a royal pita over the course of a long campaign.

Happy to be wrong, though!

EDIT: He's bloody ninja'd me again - he's getting as bad as Mick!

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Well, I suppose that depends on the environment, available equiptment, etc.

Currently my Druid build has been fighting unarmed (but she has some killer monk fists, so...).

But one of my Shifters (Kobold Commando from Mick - Yip Yip you're dead, changed to do Epic Kobold form) uses a Morningstar and does very well with it.

I would say, if you are doing well unshifted fighting unarmed (monk), then by all means go with it.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Remembering the build you're following, I can only reinforce GDL's own guidelines - which I'll admit I'd forgotten previously. You're at early levels - use your summons and familiar as physical distractions while you rain down merry hell from on high. If push comes to shove, and you really have to melee (rather than sling), I'd recommend the Monk stuff - try and get some Gloves of the Hin Fist if you can (sonic damage - very seldom resisted): you can loot them if you try often enough.

Other than them, the best gear I can recall in the OC - and stuff I've used regardless of class - is: Ring of Power (first available in chapter 3, iirc), those Sun Soul boots I mentioned in an earlier post, Golden Circlet, as many greater belts of resistance as you can afford/acquire, and the Cloak of Fortitude+3. I'll leave the other ring, shield, and the amulet slot up to you (I've always liked the necklace that prevents level drain, because I really, really hate that from years ago, but you might want some more WIS-based stuff). With those and your speedy robes, you're good to go. If you really feel the need to wear armour, the best you'll find is towards the end of chapter 3 (Red Dragon full plate), but then you'll need Boots of Speed as well.

I hope I've not thrown in any spoilers here, and equally hope this is useful for you.

Cheers

EDIT: Nooo! Not again!

Im level 10 right now and I have tested myself just solo in combat even non shifted and I can do some good damage.

I have almost no offensive spells at this point, only grease, entangle (do these spells effects stack?)and 1 call lightning that i might even swap out. So my group of 4 just roam around fully buffed and just steamroll everything so far. The toughest fight was the Lich lord? In ch2 graveyard but only because he managed to strip all my buffs and wasnt prepared the first time.

I have fought him like ten times just trying out different spells and strategies on tougher opponents. I can go toe to toe with Vardoc without help pretty easily when fully buffed. Improved expertise is amazing for those kind of warrior fights where they reliably hit and do big damage

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Ah, yes, the Tomb of Brother Toras. Utter bastard to try to beat. I confess, I try to have acquired - by fair means or foul - a belt that grants death magic resistance before going to face him. Makes life much easier. Much as an amulet that protects against level drain is hugely helpful when heading to Charwood. Just saying.

And yes, Grease and Entangle stack (though obviously not 2 of the same spells simultaneously).

Regardless of everything else, please do all of the quests you can before heading to Luskan, and then chapter 3.

You're doing well, comrade!
